original_question.content: Given that 5sin θ = 2cosθ, find the value of tan θ.

Solve, for 0 ≤ x < 360°,
5sin 2x = 2cos 2x,
giving your answers to 1 decimal place.

original_answer.content:
awrt 21.8 (α)
180+α (= 201.8), or 90+(α/2) (if division by 2 has already occurred)
(α found from tan 2x = ... or tan x = ... or sin 2x = ±... or cos 2x = ±...)
360+α (= 381.8), or 180+(α/2)
(α found from tan 2x = ... or sin 2x = ... or cos 2x = ...)
OR 540+α (= 561.8), or 270+(α/2)
(α found from tan 2x = ...)
Dividing at least one of the angles by 2
(α found from tan 2x = ... or sin 2x = ... or cos 2x = ...)
x = 10.9, 100.9, 190.9, 280.9 (Allow awrt)
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Requires the correct value with no incorrect working seen.
(Also allow awrt 68.2. ft from tan θ = \frac{5}{2} in (a), but no other ft)
(This value must be seen in part (b). It may be implied by a correct solution, e.g. 10.9)

original_question.content:
Solve, for 0 ≤ θ < 360°, the equation
9sin(θ + 60°) = 4
giving your answers to 1 decimal place.
You must show each step of your working.

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Sight of sin⁻¹(⁴⁄₉) or awrt 26.4° or 0.461°
Can also be implied for θ = awrt -33.6 (i.e. 26.4 – 60)
θ + 60° = either "180 – their α" or "360 + their α" and not for θ = either "180 – their α" or "360 + their α". This can be implied by later working. The candidate's α could also be in radians but do not allow mixing of degrees and radians.
At least one of awrt 93.6° or awrt 326.4°
Both awrt 93.6° and awrt 326.4°
Both answers are cso and must come from correct work
Ignore extra solutions outside the range.
In an otherwise fully correct solution deduct the final A1 for any extra solutions in range

original_question.content:
Solve, for −180 ≤ x < 180°, the equation
2tan x − 3sin x = 0
giving your answers to 2 decimal places where appropriate.
[Solutions based entirely on graphical or numerical methods are not acceptable.]

original_answer.content:
2(sin x / cos x) – 3sin x = 0
Note: Applies tan x = sin x / cos x
2sin x – 3sin x cos x = 0
sin x(2 – 3cos x) = 0
cos x = ⅔
x = awrt {±48.13}
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Applies tan x = sin x / cos x
can be implied by 2tan x – 3sin x = 0 ⇒ tan x(2 – 3cos x)
You can apply ft for x = ±α, where α = cos⁻¹k and -1 ≤ k ≤ 1

original_question.content:
cos²x = 8sin²x − 6sin x
(3sin x − 1)² = 2

original_answer.content:
Way 1
1-sin²x = 8sin²x-6sinx
E.g. 9sin²x-6sinx = 1
or
9 sin²x-6sinx-1=0 or
9 sin²x-6sinx+1=2
So 9sin²x-6sinx+1=2 or
(3sinx-1)²-2=0
so (3sinx-1)² = 2 or
2 = (3 sinx-1)² *
Way 2
2=(3sinx-1)² gives 9 sin²x-6sinx+1=2
so sin²x + 8sin²x-6sinx+1=2
so 8 sin²x-6sinx = 1-sin²x
8sin²x-6sinx = cos²x *
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Uses cos²x=1-sin²x
Collects sin²x terms to form a three term quadratic or into a suitable completed square format.
May be sign slips in the collection of terms.
cso This needs an intermediate step from 3 term quadratic and no errors in answer and printed answer stated but allow 2 = (3sinx-1)². If sin is used throughout instead of sinx it is A0.

original_question.content: cos²x = 8sin²x − 6sin x

original_answer.content:
Way 1: (3sinx-1) = (±)√2
sin x = 1±√2
           3
or awrt 0.8047 and awrt-0.1381
x=53.58, 126.42 (or 126.41), 352.06, 187.94
Way 2: Expands (3sinx-1)² = 2 and uses quadratic formula on 3TQ
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Square roots both sides (Way 1), or expands and uses quadratic formula (Way 2) Attempts at factorization after expanding are M0.
Both correct answers for sinx (need plus and minus). Need not be simplified.
Uses inverse sin to give one of the given correct answers
Need two correct angles (allow awrt) Note that the scheme allows 126.41 in place of 126.42 though 126.42 is preferred
All four solutions correct (Extra solutions in range lose this A mark, but outside range - ignore)
(Premature approximation:- in the final three marks lose first Al then ft other angles for second A mark)
Do not require degrees symbol for the marks
Special case: Working in radians
M1A1A0 for the correct 0.94, 2.21, 6.14, 3.28

original_question.content: 9cos²x − 11cos x + 3sin²x = 0

original_answer.content:
9cos²x-11cosx+3(1-cos²x)=0 or 6cos²x-11cosx+3(sin²x+cos²x) = 0
6cos²x-11cosx+3=0 {as (sin²x+cos²x)=1}
(3cosx-1)(2cosx-3)=0 implies cos x =
(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{3}{2})
x=70.5
x=360-"70.5"
x=289.5
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Use of sin²x =(1-cos²x) or (sin²x+cos²x)=1 in the given equation
Correct three term quadratic in any equivalent form
Uses standard method to solve quadratic and obtains cosx =
A1 for \frac{1}{3} with \frac{3}{2} ignored but A0 if \frac{3}{2} is incorrect
70.5 or answers which round to this value
360-arcos(their1/3) (or 2π - arccos(their1/3) in radians)
Second answer
Working in radians in (b) may earn M1A1M1A1B0M1A0
Extra values in the range coming from arcos (1/3) - deduct final A mark - so A0

original_question.content: $\frac{10sin^2\theta - 7cos\theta + 2}{3 + 2cos\theta} = 4 - 5cos\theta$

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Uses the identity sin²θ=1-cos²θ within the fraction.
Correct (simplified) expression in just cosθ 12-7cosθ-10cos²θ or exact equivalent such as (3+2cosθ)(4-5cosθ). Allow for 12-7u-10u² where they introduce u=cosθ. We would condone mixed variables here.
A correct attempt to factorise the numerator, usual rules. Allow candidates to use u=cosθ oe.
A fully correct proof with correct notation and no errors.
Only withhold the last mark for (1) Mixed variable e.g θ and x's (2) Poor notation cosθ -> cos²θ or sin² = 1-cos²θ within the solution.
Don't penalise incomplete lines if it is obvious that it is just part of their working

original_question.content: $\frac{10sin^2x - 7cosx + 2}{3 + 2cosx} = 4 + 3sinx$

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Attempts to use part (a) and proceeds to an equation of the form tan x = k, k≠0
Condone θ↔x. Do not condone atanx=0 ⇒ tanx=b ⇒ x=...
Alternatively squares 3sinx = -5cosx and uses sin²x = 1-cos²x oe to reach sinx = A, -1<A<1 or cosx = B, -1<B<1
Either x = awrt 121° or 301°. Condone awrt 2.11 or 5.25 which are the radian solutions.
Both x = awrt 121° and 301° and no other solutions.
Answers without working, or with no incorrect working in (b).
Question states hence or otherwise so allow
For 3 marks both x = awrt 121° and 301° and no other solutions.
For 1 mark scored SC 100 for either x = awrt 121° or 301°

original_question.content:
Solve, for -180° ≤ x < 180°,
giving your answers to 1 decimal place.
tan(x - 40°) = 1.5

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
96.3 by any or no method
Takes 180 degrees from arctan (1.5) or from their "96.3". May be implied by A1. (Could be obtained by adding 180, then subtracting 360).
awrt -83.7
Extra answers: ignore extra answers outside range. Any extra answers in range lose final A mark (if earned)
Working in radians – could earn M1 for x - 40° = -π + "0.983"... so B0M1A0

original_question.content:
Show that the equation
sinθ tanθ = 3cosθ + 2
can be written in the form
4cos²θ + 2cosθ – 1 = 0

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
uses tan θ = sin θ / cos θ or equivalent in equation (not just tan = sin / cos, with no argument)
uses sin² θ = 1 - cos² θ (quoted correctly) in equation

original_question.content:
Hence solve, for 0 ≤ θ < 360°,
showing each stage of your working.
sinθ tanθ = 3cosθ + 2

Show that the equation
tan 2x = 5 sin 2x
can be written in the form
(1 – 5 cos 2x) sin 2x = 0

original_answer.content:
States or uses tan 2x = \frac{sin 2x}{cos 2x}
\frac{sin 2x}{cos 2x} = 5 sin 2x \implies sin 2x - 5 sin 2x cos 2x = 0 \implies sin 2x (1 - 5 cos 2x) = 0 *
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Statement that tan θ = \frac{sin θ}{cos θ} or Replacement of tan (wherever it appears). Must be a correct statement but may involve θ instead of 2x.
The answer is given so all steps should be given.
N.B. sin 2x - 5sin 2x cos 2x = 0 or -5sin 2x cos 2x + sin 2x = 0 or sin 2x(\frac{1}{cos 2x} - 5) = 0 o.e. must be seen and be followed by printed answer for A1 mark
sin 2x = 5sin 2x cos 2x is not sufficient.

original_question.content:
Hence solve, for 0 ≤ x ≤ 180°,
giving your answers to 1 decimal place where appropriate.
You must show clearly how you obtained your answers.
tan 2x = 5 sin 2x

original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Statement of 0 and 180 with no working gets B1 B0 (bod) as it is two solutions
This mark for one of the two statements given (must relate to 2x not just to x)
first A1 for 39.2, second for 140.8
Special case solving cos 2x = -1/5 giving 2x = 101.5 or 258.5 is awarded M1A0A0
140.8 omitted would give M1A1A0
Allow answers which round to 39.2 or 39.3 and which round to 140.8 and allow 141
Answers in radians lose last A1 awarded (These are 0, 0.68, 1.57, 2.46 and 3.14)
Excess answers in range lose last A1 Ignore excess answers outside range.
All 5 correct answers with no extras and no working gets full marks in part (b). The answers imply the method here

Show that the equation
tan 2x = 5 sin 2x
can be written in the form
(1 – 5 cos 2x) sin 2x = 0

original_answer.content:
States or uses tan 2x = \frac{sin 2x}{cos 2x}
\frac{sin 2x}{cos 2x} = 5 sin 2x \implies sin 2x - 5 sin 2x cos 2x = 0 \implies sin 2x (1 - 5 cos 2x) = 0 *
original_answer.pedagogical_notes:
Statement that tan θ = \frac{sin θ}{cos θ} or Replacement of tan (wherever it appears). Must be a correct statement but may involve θ instead of 2x.
The answer is given so all steps should be given.
N.B. sin 2x - 5sin 2x cos 2x = 0 or -5sin 2x cos 2x + sin 2x = 0 or sin 2x(\frac{1}{cos 2x} - 5) = 0 o.e. must be seen and be followed by printed answer for A1 mark
sin 2x = 5sin 2x cos 2x is not sufficient.
